name: riddler
com:
You are the child of a single mother living in Clew Bay. Your father was a sailor whom you never met. Recently you have stumbled upon the diary of your father. The last entry is not precisely dated but it is from before you were conceived. It says that he knows two women who want a child by him - one living in Clew Bay (who, in retrospect, is your mother) and one living in Barataria Bay. He can't decide whether to have one child by each woman (two children total), or to have just one child total. So he has decided to flip a fair coin to decide. If the coin lands heads, he will have just one child total, with the woman whose bay his ship first stops by again. The diary does not record which bay his ship will first stop by again. If the coin lands tails, he will have one child by each woman (two children total), in the order of whose bays his ship first stops by again. The diary does not record the result of the coin toss.

What is the probability the coin landed heads?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15037980
>1. heads, Clew Bay first (one child in Clew Bay)
>2. heads, Barataria Bay first (one child in Barataria Bay)
>3. tails, Clew Bay first (two children one in each bay)
>4. tails, Barataria Bay first (two children one in each bay)
Each option had a 25% chance when he flipped the coin. Option 2 is impossible because, as a precondition to this problem, you are alive, so therefore only (1), (3), and (4) remain. Each of them are equally likely and only one option results in you being a only child. Therefore there is a 2/3 chance of him flipping heads.

>the 4 possible universes there is a 50% chance of me having a sibling
Universe 2 is not possible because you exist.
>if I had instead found out I was born in Barataria Bay
Then universe 1 would be impossible and the same reasoning would apply.

last_replies.name: riddler
last_replies.com:
>>15041471
>And yet you will find that in a world where parents routinely toss coins to decide whether to have 1 or 2 children, more children have siblings than not.
If you pick a random child, yes.
If you pick a random parent, no.
That is to say, if you go through a list of all parents, pick one at random, find a child by that parent, and ask that child if it has a sibling, the probability will be 1/2.
In the problem, because I match the diary, I know that I was born to a specific parent - the sailor. There was no way for my birth to be shunted as more likely to other parents just because they flipped tails on a coin toss. Therefore I know that my specific parent had a 1/2 chance of flipping heads.

>>15041481
>No, since on one of the coin tosses, you could not have existed in the first place.
Reminder that your argument is the same regardless of where I was born. As the sailor has at least one child in every result of the coin toss, I can exist in every result of the coin toss.

>>15042391
>>if I had instead found out I was born in Barataria Bay
>Then universe 1 would be impossible and the same reasoning would apply.
In other words, you are asserting that, regardless of where I was born, I have a 1/3 chance of being an only child. However, we know that whether I have a sibling was determined by a fair coin toss, so I should have a 1/2 chance of having a sibling. So there is a contradiction in your reasoning.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042410
>whether I have a sibling was determined by a fair coin toss so I should have a 1/2 chance to have a sibling
No. This is like saying in the Bertrand's box problem that you have a 1/2 chance of getting gold because you can be either in the gold box or the mixed box while ignoring the prior information given to you (that you picked a gold ball)
You have more information because you know you were born. Similar to Bertrands box, me being born makes it more likely I pick the "box" or coin flip that I was born. Probability is just a measure of uncertainty, in reality you have either a 0 or 1 chance of having a sibling because there is only one correct answer there. Since we have less uncertainty we can't just use the uncertainty from the coin flip

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15040623
1. I am the only child in Clew Bay
2. I am the only child in Barataria Bay
This is where your answer fails. You assume it was guaranteed you would be born regardless of what bay your father went to. If he didn't go to the bay you were born in, you wouldn't exist.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042410
>we know that whether I have a sibling was determined by a fair coin toss, so I should have a 1/2 chance of having a sibling.
It being decided by a fair coin toss does not imply there is a 1/2 chance of having a sibling. It implies the sailor had a 1/2 chance of having one child and a 1/2 chance of having 2.
It further implies that there was a 75% chance of you being born when he made the coin toss. Does that imply there is a 25% chance you don't exist in the current moment?

Hey guys,

I know this is going to be a controversial opinion, but I think quantum mechanics is a load of crap. I know a lot of people on this board are big fans of science and math, but I just can't get behind the idea that particles can be in multiple places at once or that they can somehow communicate with each other instantaneously. It's just too far-fetched for me.

I mean, come on, have you ever actually seen a particle in two places at once? I sure haven't. And the whole concept of quantum entanglement just doesn't make any sense to me. How can two particles that are separated by vast distances somehow be connected and know what the other is doing? It's just ridiculous.

But here's the thing: I'm not just some crank who hates science. I used to be a physics major in college, and I know enough about the subject to know that quantum mechanics doesn't add up. >The planets of solar systems in those galaxies are orbiting at this exact moment all that distance away.
this is not likely to be the case. it’s hard to fully appreciate, but these galaxies are close to 14 billion lightyears away. that means the light we’re seeing is 14 billion years old. that’s more than three times the age of our star, and our star won’t last half of that before it blows away most of its mass. so it’s reasonable to assume that most of these galaxies have totally blown apart. thinking about time in terms of “exact moments” isn’t all that intuitive when talking about the kinds of distances that exist in space. all life on earth could appear and disappear in the blink of an eye from the perspective of astronomical time

sub: Falling magnet and the conservation of energy
com:
Ok guys, since this noon there were two questiona bugging me and I am not sure if I got it right.

1) So let´s assume there is a magnet falling down near a conducting wire. The magnet induces electic current at the wire. The current than can do some electric work.

So does the magnet slow down while going near the wire transforming part of its kinetic energy into electric or is there something more to it? I mean is part of its potential energy transformed into the electric one?

2) Does falling magnet radiate electromagnetic waves? If so, does it fall slowly than nonmagnetic objects?

Sry for being a brainlet autist.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The simplest case is a magnet falling in a copper tube. Lots of videos on YouTube.

The magnet induced a current which then exerts a Lorentz force on the magnet. The magnet experiences a force that is linear in speed (if it doesn't move, there's not change in flux and no induced current. Faster motion means more current and more force.) A velocity dependent force will result in a terminal velocity (the v required for the magnetic drag force to equal the magnitude of the weight of the magnet).

A magnet falling near nothing would continually gain kinetic energy. One in a conducting tube would reach terminal velocity, with the energy being dissipated by the resistance in the tube. Additionally the magnet would emit radiation (probably very small amounts). The radiation would carry off some of the energy radially out and down ahead of the magnet.

Hope this helps anon. There are lots of good articles on magnets falling through copper tubes you cma check out for more info.

>>15040109
Laser physics phd here again.
Average day can vary a lot. I build high power lasers and we're always trying to push the limits. When I get new material to build a laser, I can spend weeks grinding in a lab testing all of its characteristics, realizing some system doesn't work, figuring out why, modifying an optical system, etc. At some point we see what would be a useful experiment and focus on that to get some results for a conference/paper etc. Tasks can vary from machining, plumbing and vacuum system assembly to developing control algorithms, splicing fiber-optic components, working with vendors to get custom optics made, getting some custom electronics working, making cad models to get components made by a workshop, or just building a particularly complex optical system. Most of us can do a little bit of everything but we're not experts in anything. Sometimes some external collaborators show up for a few days with some system they want to test with the new/upgraded laser. If the experiment works out I might spend a few weeks not doing much lab work while I write or simulate. Then either continue adding on to the current system or start over with new stuff. Luckily I build lasers from scratch and don't usually have to rely on some student's experimental laser b/c they are rarely built for long-term operation. Occasionally I jump in on other peoples experiments when they need help. Every so often an administrator asks me to put together some slides, diagrams or a video to advertise our work, or even to give a presentation or lab tour to some VIPs. Then the admin tells me to get back in the lab and make them more money. two or three times a year I travel to a conference somewhere.

Have also worked in industry and a non-uni research institute. There the tasks aren't so varied, and you have technicians for lower-level stuff like plumbing/electrical

name: Anonymous
com: Is there any kind of function or set of estimates for how the average sea level temperature on Earth would change as a function of greater or lesser distance from the sun? Like if we were 1% farther away would the temperature drop by 5°

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042140
Solar energy input per square meter (or any other unit) as a function of x, where x = distance, is 1/x^2. So, if a distance of 1 au is equal to 1 unit of energy per square unit (again, the unit doesn't matter), then increasing the distance by 0.01 au would yield 1/1.0201 = 0.98029... or a decrease of 2 %.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042140
Inverse square rule. 1% more distance ~2% less solar energy.
A very rough approximation for the Earth temp is the black body at equilibrium. So -2% emitted energy means -1.5ºC.
The orbital distance to the sun is very stable because of orbital resonance.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042171
It then stands to reason, given a linear relationship between energy input and temperature, that a decrease of 2 % should translate into a temperature that is decreased by 2 %. Considering that the average temperature of the earth is roughly 285°K, we would expect a reduction by 5.7 Kelvin yielding 279.3°K. But overall temperature of a body is actually an equistasis between energy input and radiation output, the latter being a function of T^4, which means that you're looking for a new equilibrium. Long answer short. Solar energy output increases or decreases by 1/x^2 where x = distance from the sun, but overall temperature only increases or decreases by 1/x.

Differentiate f(x,y) twice:
First wrt x, just treat y as if it were a constant
Then wrt y, just treat x as if it were a constant
You now have two "partial derivatives".
Make a vector containing both of them and now you have the "gradient".

>>15039653
[eqn] \lim_{(x,y,z) \rightarrow (2,1,-1)} 3x^2z+yx \cos(\pi (x-z))=-14 [/eqn]
In this example, the 3 variable function is
continuous everywhere in 3 dimensions, so you
evaluate each variable as normal for the answer
of -14 as your limit, regardless of path taken.
[eqn] \lim_{(x,y) \rightarrow (0,0)} {x^2y^2 \over x^4+3y^4} [/eqn]
In this one, if you set x=0 or y=0 as the path
of choice, you'll end up with a one variable
function which evaluates to zero. But, set y = x
and the limit becomes 1/4. So, the moment you
have more than one answer for the limit, it
doesn't exist.

What do you think?

last_replies.com:
>https://www.quantamagazine.org/physicists-create-a-wormhole-using-a-quantum-computer-20221130/

They're doing real cool shit. An analogy for quantum entanglement is this: imagine you amputate your arm, and ship it to China for analysis. They store it. You, in the USA, send a brain signal through your CNS to wiggle your finger in your amputated arm. The amputated arm responds and wags its finger.

The concept of a "wormhole" comes from a so-called "einstein-rosen bridge". This connects two far away regions in space via a tunnel. It'd be like walking out your house door, and instead of going into your front lawn you come out in Narnia.

They're both "action at a distance", but quantum entanglement has nothing to do with wormholes. Quantum entanglement is about information remaining coupled between two particles, despite their distance. You alter the state of one particle, and the other immediately follows tow, regardless of distance. In contrast, with a wormhole you create a portal from one region to another.

In sum, quantum entanglement requires at least two objects, whose intrinsic behaviors are coupled. A wormhole is a warping of the fabric of space that permits a single object to transport from one region to another instantly.

The only thing that the two share in common is FTL action-at-a-distance. Fuck that quanta article, the author should know better

Hey /sci/,

I have a question for you all: what's the point of science? It seems to me that all it does is create more problems and cause people to doubt everything. Every time we think we have an answer, a new study comes out that contradicts it. And for what? So we can be more "efficient" or "productive" in our daily lives? That's not living, that's just existing.

And don't even get me started on the technology that comes out of all this supposed progress. It's like we're constantly trying to outdo ourselves with the latest gadgets and gizmos, but what do they really add to our lives? Sure, they might make things easier in the short term, but they also create more stress and disconnect us from the world around us.

In my opinion, science has become a crutch for our society. We rely on it to explain away everything we don't understand, without stopping to think about the consequences. But maybe it's time for us to let go of that crutch and embrace the unknown. Who knows what we might discover if we did?

last_replies.com:
No. Why? Because the brain isn't the only feature relevant to the type of intelligence humans have. One prominent feature humans have that other animals don't is musculature and limbs structured to allow for relatively meticulous and precise tasks like constructing tools. This is why humans are physically weak for their size compared to a variety of animals of similar sizes. Their muscles are designed for things like generating speed to outrun a predator or catch prey or lifting their body weight to swing through trees as a mode of transportation without exhausting themselves. And this is without training or exercise, just a normal and expected development for those species. The design of human muscles are not conducive to feats of strength and people have to actively train for years to come close to what a chimpanzee or dog is able to do simply by waking up in the morning and being well-fed.

In summary, the brain is only one part of intelligence, the structure of the body and what behaviors and tasks an animal with such a body can perform is even more important as the brain develops hand-in-hand to enable those behaviors. Because of this, Something like Elephants or Dolphins won't develop comparable intelligence to human beings unless their bodies start to change to facilitate something like tool-making.

sub: What's happening when I'm on adderall
com:
From the perspective of one lurking sci on 4 chins
I'd like to avoid a "biological explaination", as I find this wholly unrooted in tangible existence.

When I take a high dose of adderall on occasion, say once a month or so, things feel as they ought to be.
My compulsions are essentially eliminated. There is no more compulsive behavior.
Adderall, to me, is not an "appetite suppressant", but it is eliminating compulsive consumption because 'something else' is being increased.
Rumination is eliminated. People will say something like "adhd problems with executive function" but again, this is absent existential tangibility.
My thoughts become more of a choice, and my 'intuition' is doing all the work. When I'm not on adderall, I have trended into thought-spam as a way to make sense of what it is I ought to do. When on adderall, that's not necessary. Things become a 'knowing'. I know exactly what I ought to do.
To materialise the bodies sensations into a thoughtform thus becomes a choice or a tool to assist in my lived experience. My thoughts and imagination projections become a tool to utilize on top of what it is I am actually doing. What it is I feel inclined to do, based on what I would call a heightened self-attunement.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
you're treating adhd

euphoria is unfocused, certain anons are a bit stuck in the drug war propaganda (dopamine does more than just reward signaling, and adderall does more than just flood dopamine)

it's likely an indicator that the dosage you're describing would be a reasonably therapeutic one for you. the noticeable difference is likely coming from the delay in between doses; contrary to the fearmongering ITT (and in a lot of ADHD-related threads - i blame American politics for dumping boomers all over the site), you can essentially reset your tolerance by just... taking a break from it. it's arguable that the "every day, forever" instructions that pharma loves are not the most effective way to treat ADHD with these medications, but that's another discussion.

out of curiosity, do lower doses make you sleepy as fuck? i think that's basically the strongest indicator that you're actually treating ADHD and not just experiencing mania

>The Asian flush is best known for creating a lobster-red face and neck when people drink alcohol, but the condition also results in a heightened heart rate, headache and nausea. That’s because people who turn tomato red when they drink alcohol lack activity by an enzyme called aldehyde dehydrogenase 2 (ALDH2).

Alcohol or ethanol is broken down or converted in the liver to acetaldehyde, a highly toxic compound that contributes to the hungover feeling. In most people, acetaldehyde is rapidly transformed to harmless acetate and water.

However, for some Asians, Ashkenazi Jews and others whose gene pool contains a mutant or altered form of the ALDH2 gene, the toxic acetaldehyde isn’t broken down as quickly, so it hangs around and accumulates in the liver and body — resulting in what is known as the Asian glow.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15039596
>anon they do this all the fucking time
If you look up any docs or publications by people who do research with octopi - one of the common things that comes up is that they will frequently ignore puzzles and things entirely if they aren't initially slathered in fish taste to get them interested and if the food reward inside isn't visible (which is why most puzzles have to be made of thick glass or acryllic and usually only amount to simple twisty shapes, bottles, or mazes). If the reward is removed they lose all interest. Now... true, maybe that's just a case of not having enough time to work them up to that point - but that's an inherent limit of working with cephalopods. They're very *very* short-lived (most species only live 1-3 years and even larger species like giant pacific octopuses or giant squids only live 4-5 years tops) so unless you genetically engineer cephalopods to have a longer lifespan you're going to keep running into that limit, with no guarantee that simply having more time is going to overcome that food-driven behavior.

Corvids, cetaceans, and primates likewise generally have to be trained on food rewards initially, but after even a moderate time of researchers working with the animals they can be observed to retain an interest in play and puzzle-solving regardless of rewards (rewards still make for a significantly better motivator, of course, but it's a start). Most crows and ravens live about 8-10 years in the wild (already about 2-4 times the lifespan of most cephalopods), but in human care they can live for more than double that. Primates, similarly can live for about 30-40 years. Cetaceans can, in theory, live longer than that (some species have estimated lifespans of 50-80 years), but cetaceans obviously don't do as well in prolonged captivity.

You're going to have an easier time domesticating and "uplifting" corvids than cetaceans or primates, and all three of those options are probably going to be easier than cephalopods.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15039851
have you considered that "cooperating with researchers" is not actually a sign of intelligence?

for one thing, octopuses sensing fish taste but not seeing the fish itself, then ignoring it is legitimately direct evidence that they will use multiple senses at once to make decisions, and even prioritize some more reliable ones (i.e. sight vs scent/taste that can be caused by drifting currents and provides less information about the status of the source) over others.

researchers finding it impossible to get them to go through hoops without a reward suggests that the researchers are failing to outsmart a boneless lump of mollusk, not that the subjects are 'less intelligent'

intelligence is not the same thing as trainability - the latter has more to do with trust and submission, and unfortunately cephalopods' short lifespans really hurt the ability to build trust (though as >>15037642 says, it can be extended by removing the structure that literally shuts down their production of digestive enzymes after they reproduce).

Yes, zero is a natural number. In mathematics, the natural numbers are the set of positive integers, which includes the number zero. The set of natural numbers is commonly denoted by the symbol N or the symbol Z^+. The natural numbers are also known as the counting numbers or the whole numbers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15039042
You are correct that zero apples do not exist. In the context of counting, the number zero represents the absence of a quantity or a value. When we say that there are zero apples, it means that there is no quantity or amount of apples present. In other words, there are no apples at all. This is different from saying that there is one apple, two apples, or any other non-zero quantity of apples. In the case of zero apples, there is simply no quantity to be measured or counted.

name: Anonymous
com:
if you have an endless line of numbers where each number has the same chance of being the next number in the series as the previous number, that is to say each number has an equal chance of occuring as the next number in the set, then why wouldn't this series loop at some point, repeating the previous numbers in the series to infinity?

simpy put if you randomize what number comes next then why wouldn't your endless amount of random numbers at some point randomly start repeat the previous string of numbers up to that point?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
In a truly random series of numbers, it is highly unlikely but not impossible for the sequence to repeat itself. However, the probability of this happening becomes increasingly small as the length of the sequence increases. In other words, the longer the sequence, the less likely it is for the sequence to repeat itself.
In an endless series of random numbers where each number has an equal probability of occurring, it is possible for the series to loop and repeat previous numbers. However, the probability of this happening is extremely low, especially as the series gets longer.

Imagine a series of random numbers where each number is between 1 and 10. The first number in the series could be any of the ten possible numbers. The second number could also be any of the ten possible numbers, regardless of the first number that was chosen. The third number could also be any of the ten possible numbers, regardless of the first two numbers that were chosen.

This pattern continues for an infinite number of numbers in the series. The probability that any particular sequence of numbers will occur at any point in the series is extremely low, especially as the series gets longer. For example, the probability that the sequence "1, 2, 3, 4, 5" will occur at some point in the series is 1 in 100,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 (1 in 10^60).

In other words, while it is possible for a series of random numbers to loop and repeat previous numbers, the likelihood of this happening is very small, and it is extremely unlikely to occur in an actual, practical scenario.

I do agree with most of your answer but one bit confuses me slightly, wouldn't the chance of the subsequence [math]1,2,3,4,5[/math] occurring in a sequence like this be [math]\frac{1}{10^5}[/math] considering there are only 10,000 permutations of digits possible for any fixed position in the series?

also a very slight correction for clarity to others:
>Imagine a series of random numbers where each number is between 1 and 10
Instead we'd be picking numbers from 0 to 9 but this is probably very obvious and just a small oversight

and finally on the looping thing (also >>15040267) - since our sequence is infinite and the digits within it are uniformly distributed, I think every finite subsequence (which would thus be only finitely improbable to appear) would occur with a probability of 1. note this is not the same thing as saying it must necessarily occur, though, and this includes the probability that the sequence will repeat it's starting values any finite number of times.

Given a fixed index [math]k \in \mathbf{N}[/math] the probability that [math]\{S_1, S_2, \dots, S_k\}= \{S_{k+1}, S_{k+2}, \dots, S_{k+k}\}[/math] is [math]\frac{1}{10^k}[/math].
Then the probability that there is no such k anywhere in S is [math]\prod_{k=k_0}^{\infty}{1 - \frac{1}{10^k}}=0[/math], considering that [math]P(k) := 1 - \frac{1}{10^k} < 1[/math] and [math]P(k+1) < P(k) \forall k \in N[/math].
Thus the probability that the sequence will not repeat a finite number of it's initial digits eventually is 0. Somewhat counterintuitively this is not the same as saying that a sequence of finite size must be repeated necessarily, but it's very likely it will happen somewhere. It can similarly be shown that any finite number of these repetitions (say, 50 repetitions in a row) will occur with probability 1, but this is not the case for an infinite loop.
